metadata.sermon_title: King of Kings and Lord of Lords
metadata.notes: Christ the King Sunday. Preached by a veteran clergyman as a 'parting witness' to a specific congregation (Westerly).

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher uses a 'Corrective Parent' tone, critiquing modern culture (Woodstock, PC culture, Barney) and academic theology. There is a clear 'must' regarding how the Bible is read.
quotes: No more rulers, no more lords, no more kings.
It’s not right to try to make it say what it clearly doesn’t say.
I must take these few moments to bear witness...

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The care is present but tied to submission to the 'King.' It offers comfort through the sovereignty of God, which can be supportive but also promotes dependency on a higher authority rather than internal agency.
quotes: My son belongs to God. Nothing can change that... I can let it go.

adult.analysis: The preacher engages in historical and linguistic analysis (kurios, basileus), which is Adult-to-Adult. However, he eventually dismisses 'reason' and 'common sense' in favor of a Parent-driven 'scandal' of faith.
quotes: Lord (kurios) has the same essential meaning as king (basileus).
It’s an offense (skandalon) against all reason and common sense.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher evokes the Adapted Child by highlighting the listener's failures and lack of control, pushing them into a position of submission to the 'King.'
quotes: Why hasn’t your career gone the way you had hoped? Why is your marriage troubled?
We are not in control of our lives.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is very little spontaneity or joy. The 'Lion King' and 'Barney' references are used as Critical Parent foils rather than Free Child playfulness.
quotes: It’s pretty funny, actually; the power of certain symbols...

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher positions himself as the authoritative elder (Parent) addressing a congregation that has been 'misled' by modern culture (Child). He invites the congregation to stop trying to be 'masters of their fate' and return to a submissive role.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Socially, it is an invitation to 'believe the Bible.' Psychologically, it is a demand to 'surrender control and admit helplessness.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the move from historical analysis (Adult) to a sudden personal attack on the listener's life success (Parent), catching the listener off-guard.

detected_games.name: NIGYSOB (Now I've Got You, You Son of a Bitch)

formula_g_analysis.con: Let's talk about the history of kingship and movies.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire to feel in control of their life.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Suddenly asking why the listener's marriage and career are failing.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels small/guilty; the preacher's 'King' is the only solution.

evidence_quotes: Whom do we want to be ruler of our lives? ... Then why hasn’t your career gone the way you had hoped? Why is your marriage troubled?

detected_games.name: Ain't It Awful

formula_g_analysis.con: Modern culture has lost its way.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: Shared frustration with 'political correctness' or 'liberal' theology.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A collective sense of being a persecuted but 'correct' remnant.

evidence_quotes: Everything was supposed to be egalitarian... no amount of political correctness is going to make much headway.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. He offers the 'Kingship of Jesus' as the only way to handle the 'world of Sin and Death.'
preacher_roles.persecutor: Medium. He judges the 'mainline churches' and the listener's personal life failures.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. Slight hint of the 'lonely witness' who won't be back to preach again.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Pushed into the Victim role (helpless against death, failing in marriage/career) so they will accept the Rescuer's solution.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Minimal. The sermon suggests that 'autonomy' (being captain of one's soul) is the root of the problem, thus discouraging the Adult ego position.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is a classic example of Parent-Child homiletics. While theologically orthodox in its emphasis on sovereignty, it psychologically functions by stripping the listener of Adult agency. It uses 'shame-baiting' (pointing out troubled marriages/careers) to force a 'switch' into a state of helplessness. The narrative of the grieving father is powerful but is used to reinforce a 'Victim' position that can only be solved by total surrender to an external 'King,' rather than fostering a mature, Adult faith that co-operates with the Divine.
strengths: Strong use of narrative and cultural symbols.
High emotional resonance in the final third.
areas_for_improvement: Over-reliance on Critical Parent judgments of 'modernity.'
Manipulative use of personal failure (marriage/career) to score theological points.
Lack of Adult-to-Adult invitation for the listener to process the 'scandal' themselves.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try to address the congregation as fellow Adults who can choose to follow the King out of Free Child joy rather than Adapted Child fear. Avoid using the listener's potential personal 'failures' as a Gimmick to prove a theological point.
